title: Richard Hutson
text:
Richard Hutson (1747 – April 12, 1795) was a <a href="Founding%20Fathers%20of%20the%20United%20States">Founding Father of the United States</a> and an American lawyer, judge, and politician from <a href="Charleston%2C%20South%20Carolina">Charleston, South Carolina</a>. He was born in June 1747 to Rev. William Hutson and Mary Hutson (nee Woodward). His family moved to Charleston in 1756 when his father was the pastor at the <a href="Circular%20Congregational%20Church">Circular Congregational Church</a>. After having been educated in Charleston as a child, he attended <a href="Princeton%20University">Princeton</a>.
In 1778 and 1779 he represented <a href="South%20Carolina">South Carolina</a> as a delegate to the <a href="Continental%20Congress">Continental Congress</a>, where he signed the <a href="Articles%20of%20Confederation">Articles of Confederation</a>. After the British captured Charleston in 1780, he was held as a prisoner at <a href="St.%20Augustine%2C%20Florida">St. Augustine, Florida</a>, for a time. After he returned home, he served as the eighth <a href="List%20of%20lieutenant%20governors%20of%20South%20Carolina">lieutenant governor of South Carolina</a> under Governor <a href="John%20Mathews%20%28lawyer%29">John Mathews</a> in 1782 and 1783. On September 11, 1783, Hutson was elected the first intendant (mayor) of Charleston. He was re-elected on September 13, 1784, winning against Alexander Gillon by a vote of 387 to 127. After his time as intendant of Charleston, he was one of the first three chancellors of the Court of Equity of South Carolina.
He is buried in a vault at the Independent Congregational (Circular) Churchyard in Charleston.
